COLL_NOTES: It is assumed that fishes used for stomach content analysis were collected by the charter boat sports fishery in the Gulf of Mexico north of Tampa, but specifically around Panama City and Destin, FL. This is the location of the king mackerel fishery from May to October, which is the time period (spring and summer) that the author indicates the stomachs were collected.
Collected at 1955 Alabama Deep Sea Fishing Rodeo
Collected at 1955 Alabama Deep Sea Fishing Rodeo

Trawling times varied from 10 minutes to 2 hours depending on the depth and bottom conditions. Most tows were for 30 minutes. 98 bottom trawl samples were taken in 1970, 84 in 1971, 118 in 1972. From June 1973 to January 1974, 36 trawl samples were taken in areas where a shrimp fleet was working. In June, July and August 1974, 45 samples were taken with the fleet. Trawling sampling depths ranged between 5.5 and 173.7 m. Field work was accomplished from aboard the Texas Parks and Wildlife vessel Western Gulf. An attempt was made to take samples at 9.1 m intervals each month, with supplementary sampling as time allowed. The majority of collections were obtained between 7.3 and 64.0 m off shore of Port Aransas and Freeport-Galveston.

GEAR_NOTES: Seine Net is 16,000 meshes long and 1,000 meshes wide.  Completed, the net is 1,125 ft (342.9 m) long and 85 ft (25.908 m) deep

COLL_NOTES: Collected at 1971 Texas International Fishing Tournament

In fishing, baited hooks are suspended approximately one to three feet above the sea floor. Once a fish is caught and hauled onto the deck, it is unhooked by inserting a short pole into the gape and allowing the line to coil around it. A sudden thrust extracts the hook. The fish are drawn, but the viscera and the blood are not always entirelyremoved or is the fish rinsed off properly.
FIELD_PRES_NOTES: Icing takes place within 2 hours of the time the fish are caught. The fish are placed on ice with their drawn sides down, to permit drainage. Ice separates each layer of fish; the top layer is more hevily iced.

Icing takes place within 2 hours of the time the fish are caught. The fish are placed on ice with their drawn sides down, to permit drainage. Ice separates each layer of fish; the top layer is more hevily iced.

GEAR_NOTES: Injections of Alkaline formalin method (borax solution) into the lumen shortly after capture was proven ineffective  and was abandoned.

Fishes were collected from the Clear Lake area and its tributaries with a 3m otter  trawl. A 6mm bar mesh cover was used over the cod end or the trawl during some of the sampling to capture post larval fish, many of which were less than 15mm in length. The larger bar of mesh of the trawl  19mm and 13 mm in the body and length . The larger bar of mesh of trawl, 19 mm and 13mm in the body and cod end, respectively, permitted many of the smaller fish to escape when the cover was not used.

12.2 meter semiballon, rigged with tickler chain, 2.4 m by 1.0 m wooden doors.
COLL_NOTES: Towed at 3 knots. All trawls made at night.

GEAR_NOTES: 186 m long monofiliment net, comprised of 6 panels of stretch mesh, ranging from sizes 7.6 to 14.0 cm in steps of 1.3 cm.
DIET_ANALYSIS_METHODS: 5 fish from each sampling event were chosen at random. The contents of the entire GI were extruded and collected in a 25 mL scintillation and preserved in a 2% Glutaraldehyde solution and kept refrigerated until analsis. Initally, 1.0 mL of the gut contents solution was put separately into different Petri dishes and diluted with water until the bottom of the dish was covered. The sample matter was allowed  to settle for 20 minutes and then inspected at 20X and 40X magnifications.

COLL_NOTES: Field work was conducted from a small outboard boat. A systematic sampling survey, consisting of several passes through the 2m wide study transect, was made on eight occasions between August, 1970 and July, 1971. Studies on food habits of the red snapper, Lutjanus campechanus (Poey), were conducted by James K. Davis concurrently with the present study.

GEAR_NOTES: 12.2 m semi-baloon trawl having a 12.2 m float line and a 13.8 m lead line. The trawl was constructed of 47.6 mm stretched mesh, untreated nylon (#18 twine) throughout the body and 38.1 m stretched mesh nylon (#30 twine) in the cod end. Untreated nylon webbing prevented contamination of samples taken for hydrocarbon analysis. A 2/O galvanizxed "tickler" chain was attached to the 2.4 x 1.0 m mahogany trawl doors to enhance capture of demersal organisms.
COLL_NOTES: Three 20-min trawl tows were made at each station. Trawls were towed at a vessel speed of approximately 2 knots along one or more sides of a triangle formed by three bouys marking the station. Trawls were towed at night to minimize net avoidance.
FIELD_PRES_NOTES: sorted finfish collections weighing less than 9 kg were placed in plastic bags, properly labeled and quick frozen.

GEAR_NOTES: Line fishing was conducted using electric reels and a range of hook sizes (#2 through 4/0 Mustad hooks). Terminal tackle consisted of lead weights (250 to 907 g) and two or three hooks baited with squid. Hook and line fishing was concentrated during the bours between 1900 and 0200, although collections were made on all cruises during most hours of the day.
COLL_NOTES: Sampling was conducted aboard research vessels during eight seasonal (winter, January; spring, April/May; summer, July/August; and fall, Oct/Nov) criuses between October 1980 and October 1982. Fish were weighed (g) and measured (mm fork length: FL) upon capture. The position and depth of all collecting stations and time of capture was recorded.
FIELD_PRES_NOTES: rinsed in running water and blotted dry prior to examination
LAB_PRES_NOTES: Partially digested fish prey were cleared with trypsin and stained with alcian blue and alizarin red so that meristic counts could be used for identification.
DIET_ANALYSIS_METHODS: The contents of stomachs and intestines (excluding caecum) were placed in separate bowls and examined with a binocular microscope equipped with an ocular micrometer. Individual prey items were identified to lowest taxon possible, counted, and measured along their greatest extent.

GEAR_NOTES: Paired 25 m monofilament gill nets (75 cm2 stretch mesh) were occasionally used on the reefs. Gill nets were placed early in the evening and retrieved the following day.

DIET_ANALYSIS_METHODS: Ideally, only the stomach contents were examined; however, if the stomach was empty or only partially filled, the intestinal contents were also inspected. For caridean and penaeid shrimp, crabs, and mysids, material for examination was taken from the bucal cavity. For insect larvae, amphipods, cumaceans and isopods the method of Croker (1967) was used.

For insect larvae, amphipods, cumaceans and isopods the method of Croker (1967) was used.

COLL_NOTES: In muddy areas with steep banks or along open shores, the 30.5m seine was set quickly in a semi-circle from the stern of the boat and slowly pulled ashore. The 12.2m seine was then pulled to shore for approximately 20m in an adjacent area. In shallow grass flats, both seines were set parallel to shore at a depth of about 1m and then pulled to shore. In Tampa Bay, each station was sampled bi-weekly from Sept. to Dec. 1981. Begining in Jan. 1982, sampling was limited to once every three weeks in the Alafia River. In July 1982, 6 stations were added (13-18).
DIET_ANALYSIS_METHODS: Black drum diets were described from contents of the entire alimentary tract in larvae and in the stomach (that portion of the alimentary tract between the esophagus and pylorus) in juveniles. Contents were identified to the lowest possible taxon. Fullness was estimated subjectively on a scale of 0 (empty) to 5 (full). Volumes were measured by displacementor, for items < 0.05cm3, by a squash method.

A standard otter trawl with a 10-ft opening. The otter boards were 10x24 inches in size. The wings of the trawl net were netting with a mesh size of 7/8 in on the side or 1 3/4 in stretched measure. The cod end was made of heavy twine with a mesh size of 1/2 in on the side or 1 in stretched. An inner liner was inserted inside the cod end. The mesh of the liner measured 3/16 in on the side or 3/8 in stretched. Trawl tows were made both in straight lines and in circles and were timed to 10 min duration.
Seine net had a mesh size of 3/8 in on the side or 3/4 in stretched. Seining started at a depth of approx. 4 ft, stretched parallel to shore and pulled straight in.
Net was 20 ft. The mesh was 1/4 in on the side or 1/2 in stretched.

Trammel net was 1200 ft long.2 methods used: playing the net out of a skiff parallel to shore then creating a disturbance to cause fish to swim into net. Method 2: "cork-screwing" the net - playing the net out in a circle, leaving the end in the skiff. One person continues to pull the leading end of the net around at the same time decreasing the diameter of circle while helpers feed other end into the boat.

COLL_NOTES: Three research cruises were conducted in May, July, and September of 2005, and two cruises were conducted in June and August 2006. Stations were sampled between the hours of 0700 and 1900 h. Both nets were fished simultaneously at 2.5 - 3.5 kts fot approximately 10 minutes. Towing distance was determined by difference in start and stop locations from GPS and from a flowmeter placed inside each net.

Both nets were fished simultaneously at 2.5 - 3.5 kts fot approximately 10 minutes. Towing distance was determined by difference in start and stop locations from GPS and from a flowmeter placed inside each net.

GEAR_NOTES: 25 x 6 m aberturia de malla de 1 mm (see p. 22)

COLL_NOTES: During all months of the year. Collected from approximately 0900 to 1300 h primarialy using SCUBA
FIELD_PRES_NOTES: Typically packed in ice overnight, and processed the day after collection. In the early stages of the study, the stomach and intestine from each specimen were labeled, wraped in cheesecloth, and frozen until further analysis. During later collections, stomach contents were processed immediately upon removal from the specimen. All prey items were stored in 70% ethanol and retained as voucher specimens.
DIET_ANALYSIS_METHODS: Digestive tracts were removed by cutting the esophagus directly anterior to the heart and as near the anus as possible. Prior to examination, stomachs were thawed, contents removed, and prey items identified to the lowest possible taxonomic level. Known bait items from specimins caught by angling were noted and discarded. Intestinal contents were initally surveyed but this was later discontinued due to the lack of identifiable prey contents. Prey items were blotted dry and weighed to the nearest 0.01 g
